title: Chapter 7 Bankruptcy. Turning money over to Trustee.
question: Pro Se in my BK.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,341 meeting of creditors,Bankruptcy trustee,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Renting a house or apartment,Representing yourself
answers: I agree with previous attorneys. You future income is generally not the property of the bankruptcy estate in Chapter 7 (with certain exceptions) and you are free to dispose of the exempt assets. Your question is not detailed enough, however, to be able to provide you with the full answer. You definitely need help to fix the issues (likely amend schedules and have trustee abandon any rights in the future income arising out of the script sale if it is not worth much, that is unless you already have a contract for the script sale and trustee is aware of that).

What is your screenplay worth right now, without being finished? The Chapter 7 Trustee isn't entitled to take work you do in the future to pay the creditors, nor is the Trustee entitled to prevent you from selling property that is otherwise exempt.

My concern is that if you filed your bankruptcy without an attorney representing you, you have already shot yourself in the foot. Hopefully, the volunteer lawyers in your community will be able to straighten things out for you.

Hope this perspective helps!

More likely than not, the items you mentioned that you would like to sell are exempt. However, I agree with the other attorney that you need a qualified attorney to review your schedules to make sure you properly exempted the assets. If they are fully exempt the Trustee would likely not have a problem with you selling to earn money and make ends meet, as those assets would be abandoned by the estate.

The idea of bankruptcy is to give a debtor a fresh start. No one expects you to liquidate all your assets to pay your bills to live -- that's why certain assets are exempted from a bankruptcy estate. You can do whatever you wish with your exempt assets, which typically includes basic furnishings and other assets in which the Trustee has expressed no interest.

Reading between the lines, it seems that you are working full-time on your screenplay which you hope to sell. It also sounds as if the rental income is your only income.

Presumably you have been working on the screenplay to the exclusion of everything else including earning any money to take care of basic necessities.

Without more info from what the Trustee said, the Trustee seems to be taking the position that you cannot forestall paying creditors, file bankruptcy and then walk away from those debts while collecting a payday from the sale of your screenplay.

You are learning the consequences of doing a bankruptcy by yourself -- you have no one to advocate on your behalf with the Trustee or give you advice what to do either before filing for bankruptcy or during the case itself to deal with a situation where a 120 day case now threatens to be 3 times as long.

You may wish to consult with a bankruptcy attorney who can give you some advice. However, this case seems to be pretty far along and unless the attorney is a friend, I am not optimistic how willing an attorney would be to give you free advice at this point. There are organizations geared for providing legal assistance (often free) to artists -- NY has them ("Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts"); I would be surprised if LA does not. You should check around.

Good luck.

You need to use exemptions if available to protect the potential revenue. If you are in southern California contact the bankruptcy court and ask about the self help desk. Their are volunteer attorneys who you can see that maybe able to assist you.

I personally volunteer at the woodland hills bankruptcy court. I will be there at one on July 12th.

You must get help from a qualified Attorney. In order to properly assist you the Attorney needs to examine your schedules.
